learning_outcomes: Master the use of inversion for rhetorical effect
Use cleft sentences to focus on specific information
Identify formal contexts where these structures are appropriate

content.prompt_es: Reescribe la frase comenzando con la expresión negativa para dar énfasis (Inversion):
content.stimulus_en: I have never seen such a beautiful sunset. (NEVER)
content.correct_answer: Never have I seen such a beautiful sunset.
content.explanation: When we start a sentence with a negative adverb like 'never', we use question word order (auxiliary before subject).

options.text: Little he knew about the surprise waiting for him.
Little did he know about the surprise waiting for him.
Little he did know about the surprise waiting for him.

content.explanation: 'Little' at the beginning of a sentence requires inversion of the auxiliary 'did'.

content.prompt_es: Transforma esta frase en una 'It-cleft' para enfatizar al sujeto (John):
content.correct_answer: It was John who broke the window.
content.explanation: An 'It-cleft' structure is 'It + is/was + emphasized part + relative clause'.

content.prompt_es: Completa la 'What-cleft' para enfatizar la acción:
content.stimulus_en: I need a long holiday. -> ________ I need is a long holiday.
content.explanation: A 'What-cleft' (pseudo-cleft) uses a nominal relative clause to focus on a specific part of the sentence.
